identificationModule.briefTitle: Casting vs Bracing for Idiopathic Early-Onset Scoliosis
identificationModule.officialTitle: Casting vs Bracing for Idiopathic Early-Onset Scoliosis

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Comparison of casting and bracing for the treatment of idiopathic early onset scoliosis
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: This study uses a multicenter, prospective hybrid research design, which will combine two methods of treatment assignment (randomized and parent preference) and an embedded internal pilot study for sample size re-estimation. Patients will be treated either with serial casts or a full-time brace and followed until curve resolution, failure or palliation (neither resolution nor failure after 2 years of treatment). Results of this study will provide clinicians and families with evidence to support informed treatment decisions.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Treatment (casting or bracing) via randomized assignment OR based on family preference

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: Study outcome is determined from serial radiographs. Radiographic readers will be blinded to the treatment assigned or received.

armGroups.label: Casting
armGroups.description: Subjects will be treated with serial casting

armGroups.label: Bracing
armGroups.description: Subjects will be treated with full-time orthotics (braces)

interventions.name: Casting
interventions.description: Use of casts applied using corrective maneuvers

primaryOutcomes.description:
Resolution - curve improvement to \<15 degrees (as measured on 2 consecutive radiographs)

Failure

1. Initial Cobb 20-50° (inclusive): curve progression of ≥20° resulting in a curve ≥50°
2. Initial Cobb \>50°: curve progression of ≥20°

Palliation - 2 years of treatment without resolution or failure
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: on or before 24 months of treatment

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluation of patients' HRQOL as estimated by serial administrations of the Early Onset Scoliosis Questionnaire (EOSQ-24, completed by the parent at baseline and every 6 months, total score range 0-100, higher scores indicate higher level of HRQOL). Within and between treatment arm comparisons will be made.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: on or before 24 months of treatment

otherOutcomes.description: Evaluation of patients' disease and treatment on parent and family function as estimated by serial administrations of the PedsQL Family Impact Module scores (PedsQL FIM, completed by the parent, total score range 0-100, higher scores indicate less negative impact). Within and between treatment arm comparisons will be made.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: on or before 24 months of treatment

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Will enroll both patients with scoliosis and 1 of their parents/guardians

Inclusion Criteria:

Patient Inclusion

* Diagnosis of idiopathic early-onset scoliosis
* Child standing independently but not older than 3 years of age
* 20≤ Cobb angle ≤70° (largest structural curvature)
* Rib-vertebral angle difference (RVAD) greater than 20 degrees or Rib Phase II
* Parental consent to participate

Parent Inclusion

* Parent or guardian of the minor subject
* Consent to participate
* Able to complete surveys

Exclusion Criteria:

Patient Exclusion

* Previous operative or non-operative treatment for idiopathic early-onset scoliosis
* Not independently walking by 18 months of age or other signs/symptoms indicative of developmental delay

locations.facility: Nemours/Alfred I. duPont Hospital for Children
Riley's Hospital for Children at IU Healthcare
University of North Carolina Chapel Hill

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: All study data (assessments and images) will reside in the Pediatric Spine Registry.
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: after our planned analyses and publications are completed
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: Study data will be available to all CVBT investigators and Pediatric Spine Registry participants. Interested parties will prepare a proposal for consideration by the PI and the Pediatric Spine Study Group. If approved, the Pediatric Spine Registry staff will query the database and provide the required data for secondary analysis.

browseBranches.name: Diseases and Abnormalities at or Before Birth
